entry.title: Story Performance Analysis Tool in Report Center: New in 1H 2025!
entry.content:
Overview

The recent enhancements to the People Analytics module for the 1H 2025 have proven to be highly impactful. A particularly noteworthy enhancement is the ability to assess and optimize the efficiency of Story reports.

The Story Performance Analysis Tool, accessible via Report Center, enables Story administrators to assess, monitor, measure and optimize the efficiency of Story reports and captures detailed performance metrics, helping identify areas for improvement and enhance overall report performance. This enhancement aims to bring greater visibility and control over the performance aspects of Stories.

Benefits of Story Performance Analysis Tool: -

The Story Performance Analysis Tool delivers significant value to various user groups, including HR administrators, managers, and analytics power users:

  • For Administrators:

- Helps identify bottlenecks or inefficiencies in report design or data handling and minimizes report loading delays
- Allows for proactive performance tuning, such as optimizing filters, chart components, or data models.
- Reduces reliance on IT teams by giving admins tools to self-diagnose issues.

  •  For End Users (Managers, HRBPs, etc.):

- Ensures faster access to performance-critical reports and improves data-driven decision-making ensuring reports load reliably.
- Leads to a better user experience with less waiting time and smoother navigation.

  • Overall Organizational Benefits:

- Saves time and effort by eliminating guesswork around report performance issues.
- Helps maintain reporting integrity and reliability in strategic HR processes like performance management, compensation reviews.

What You’ll Need:-

For successful utilization of this enhancement, make sure:

  • You have access to Stories in Report Center.
  • You have the Role-Based Permission Prerequisites: - Administrator > Manage Dashboards/Reports > Story Admin

Now let’s walk through the Procedure to utilize the Story Performance Analysis Tool: -

Step 1.  To access the Performance Analysis Tool, choose Story Performance Analysis Tool from the Report Center.

 

Landing Page of the Performance Analysis Tool:-

Step 2.  To set the date range:

  1. Click the Session Date token.
  2. Adjust the existing range or add a new range.

Step 3.  To apply additional filters:

  1. Click on User or Resource
  2. Select the appropriate member(s).

Step 4.  In the list of results, click to select the report/item to analyze.

 

The report is analyzed in 3 sections namely -

  • Summary
  • Details
  • History

a.) Summary Section

The Summary section provides a top-level overview of the total performance footprint of the Story report. It captures the end-to-end load time, determine where high-level delays are occurring and distributes it across the 3 primary system layers involved in report execution:

 Network – Time spent in data transfer between the server and the client

 Backend – Time taken to retrieve and prepare data from the data model

Frontend – Time taken to render charts, tables, and visuals on the user interface.

- Under Summary section,

  • Startup Time displays – The Timespan from the initiation of the Actions "Open" and "Go to Page to the finalized page.
  • Total Widget Time displays – The sum of all usage times for each Widget, including multiple uses.
  • Maximum Backend Duration displays – The maximum backend processing time per model, noting totals may rise with multiple widgets or refreshes. 
  • Maximum Widget Time and Total Widget Time displays – Maximum and median processing times per layer (frontend, backend, network) across all widgets during user interactions

 

b.) Details Section

The Details section provides a granular breakdown of performance data, offering visibility into how specific report components contribute to overall load time. This includes: - Performance of individual pages within the Story, Load time of specific widgets, such as charts, graphs, or tables, Execution time for backend queries, including filtering, sorting, and data transformation

It is used by admins to troubleshoot performance bottlenecks and identifies exact sources of delay, facilitates targeted optimizations, reduces trial-and-error during report tuning.

- Under Details section,

  • Page Load Time displays – Total load time per story page, split by phase, with peak backend, frontend, and network times
  • Widget Drilldown displays – Widget load time with action, page, model, and backend request details.
  • Loading Sequence displays - Widget load time by action, split into backend, network, and frontend

 

c.) History Section

The History section records a time-stamped log of previous performance analyses conducted on the same Story report. It enables comparison of performance metrics across different test runs or after configuration changes.

It supports trend analysis and performance benchmarking over time and tracks performance improvements or regressions, provides historical evidence of tuning efforts, supports continuous monitoring for business-critical reports

Under History section,

  • Total Time per Date displays – Charts compare a user's performance history with others, switching measures based on filters like page, action, or widget.
  • Runtime Split per Date displays – Charts compare a single user’s runtime performance (median backend, network, frontend times) against all users, independent of filters.

 

Step 5.  Take Action Based on Insights: -

  1. Optimize charts and pages with high frontend time.
  2. Adjust or reduce filters and calculations affecting backend time.
  3. Collaborate with your technical team if network issues persist.

Administrators/Users also have the option –

  • To enable the Show in Milliseconds toggle which will display the Time in milliseconds
  • To apply filters as per the requirement

You've reached the end of this process!

With minimal effort, administrators can directly access Story Performance Analysis Tool within Report Center, enhancing ability to assess and optimize the efficiency of Story reports and identifying areas for improvement and optimize report performance.

I hope this blog added value to your learning journey. Feel free to like, share your thoughts in the comments, and spread the word! Keep learning and growing.

entry.title: Enable Social Login & 2FA for External Candidates in SAP SuccessFactors via SAP Customer Data Cloud
entry.content:
In Q4 2024, SAP SuccessFactors introduced a robust authentication mechanism for external candidates through SAP Customer Data Cloud (CDC). This enhancement delivers a fast, seamless, and secure login experience by enabling job seekers to login using email, phone number, or social credentials (such as Google or LinkedIn), while supporting two-factor authentication (2FA) for added security.

This blog provides a step-by-step guide to help you configure social login providers and 2FA for external candidates on your SAP SuccessFactors career site using the SAP CDC Console.

Overview of the Social Provider Integration Process

The integration involves three primary steps:

  1. Registering an Application with the social media provider

  2. Configuring the Identity Provider in SAP Customer Data Cloud

  3. Enabling the Social Login in the UI Builder of the SAP CDC Console

While steps 2 and 3 are consistent across providers, step 1 varies depending on the platform. Below are detailed instructions for Google and LinkedIn, followed by high-level guidelines for other providers.

A. Google Login Setup

Step 1: Register an application with Google

1.1 Access Google Cloud Console
Navigate to https://console.cloud.google.com and either create a new project or select an existing one.


1.2 Enable the Google People API

Go to API & Services > Library, search for Google People API, and click Enable. 

 

1.3 Create OAuth Credentials

Click Create Credentials and follow the next steps.


 

1.3.1 Credential Type

Under "What data will you be accessing", select the "User Data" radio button. 

1.3.2 Configure OAuth Consent Screen

Provide the following details :

  • App name (e.g., Candidate Login App)

  • App logo (mandatory; tools like Adobe Express can help)

  • Developer contact email

 

1.3.3 Scopes

This section is optional and can be skipped.

1.3.4 Configure OAuth Client ID

  • Application Type: Web Application

  • Name: A name for the credential (e.g., Google Login)

  • Authorized JavaScript origins: Use the base URL of your SAP SuccessFactors Career Site, such as:

    https://career68sales.successfactors.com

  • Authorized Redirect URIs:

    https://socialize.gigya.com/GS/GSLogin.aspx?  (Mandatory)
    https://socialize.<DataCenter>/GS/GSLogin.aspx? - 
    Replace the "DataCenter" field using the below link(e.g., https://socialize.us1.gigya.com/GS/GSLogin.aspx?)
    Ensure to include the trailing question mark (?) — it is required for successful redirects. Refer to Finding your Data Center to find the details of your data center.

1.3.5 Download and Note Your Credentials

Once completed, you'll be shown the Client ID and Client Secret — save these securely, as you'll need them in the next step when configuring CDC.

Step 2: Configure Google as an Identity Provider in SAP CDC

  1. Open the Identity Providers page of SAP Customer Data Cloud's Console.
  2. From the list of Identity Providers, select Google.
  3. Click on Google to open its configuration window.


  4. In the Google Configuration window enter:

    • Your "Client ID" from the Google Developers Dashboard into the "Consumer Key" field. (The entire string, including .apps.googleusercontent.com)
    • Your "Client Secret" into the "Secret Key" field.
    • Select Secure redirects only to allow only HTTPS redirects from Google.

Step 3: Enable Google Login in SAP CDC UI Builder

By default, the Login & Registration screen-set on the career site displays only basic authentication (email and password). To display the Social Login widget, follow these steps:

  1. Select a screen-set: Choose either the Registration or Login screen-set where you want to enable social login.

  2. In the Properties section:

    • Remove the gigya-hidden CSS class from the social widget (and also for the separator elements in the Login screen).

    • In the Supported Providers field, enter a comma-separated list of the social login providers to display — for example: googleplus,linkedin,facebook

These changes will make the Google social provider visible to external candidates on the career site.

B. LinkedIn Login Setup

Step 1: Register an Application with LinkedIn

  1. Visit the LinkedIn Developer Portal.

  2. Create a new app and fill in the required details.



  3. Request access for sign in with linkedIn using openId connect



  4.  Navigate to the Auth tab and set the below Redirect URLs :

    4.1) The URL should be in the format "https://socialize.<DataCenter>/GS/GSLogin.aspx?" where  <DataCenter> can be found out using     Finding your Data Center.  Be sure to include the trailing question mark (?)  as it is required for successful redirects.

    4.2) The URL of your career site - for example, https://career68sales.successfactors.com



  5.  Under Settings -> Additional settings, add the above redirect URL's domain (ex. "https://socialize.us1.gigya.com")
    and that of your career site (ex. https://career68sales.successfactors.com)


  6. Save and note the Client ID and Client Secret, as these will be used in the next step.

Step 2: Configure LinkedIn as an Identity Provider in SAP CDC

  1. Open the Identity Providers page of SAP Customer Data Cloud's Console.

  2. Select LinkedIn from the list of supported providers.

  3. Paste your LinkedIn "API Key (Client ID)" and "Secret Key (Client Secret)" in the corresponding fields.

  4. Select Secure redirects only to allow only HTTPS redirects from Linkedin.
  5. Select Application Type as "Sign In with LinkedIn using OpenID Connect"
  6. Select the permission "Enable retrieving email address".

Step 3: Enable Linkedin Login in the SAP CDC UI Builder

By default, the Login & Registration screen-set on the career site displays only basic authentication (email and password). To display the Social Login widget, follow these steps:

  1. Select a screen-set: Choose either the Registration or Login screen-set where you want to enable social login.

  2. In the Properties section:

    • Remove the "gigya-hidden" CSS class from the social widget (and also for the separator elements in the Login screen).

    • In the Supported Providers field, enter a comma-separated list of the social login providers to display — for example: googleplus,linkedin,facebook

These changes will make the Linkedin social provider visible to external candidates on the career site.

Extending to Other Social Login Providers

The process for integrating other social login providers, such as Facebook, Twitter, Apple, or GitHub, follows a similar pattern:​

  1. Register an application with the respective provider to obtain the necessary credentials.

  2. Configure the provider in the SAP CDC Console by entering the required credentials from the application.

  3. Enable the provider in the SAP CDC Console's UI Builder to make it available as a login option.​

For detailed guidance on integrating additional providers, refer to the SAP Customer Data Cloud documentation.​

Enabling Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) in SAP Customer Data Cloud

Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) enhances login security by requiring users to verify their identity through a second method, such as email, SMS, or an authenticator app. SAP Customer Data Cloud supports all three options.

Follow the steps below to enable 2FA for external candidates in SAP SuccessFactors using SAP CDC:

Step 1: Enable Email Identity Verification (Required for Email 2FA)

Before enabling email-based 2FA, ensure email identity verification is active:

  1. Navigate to Identity → Security in the CDC Console.

  2. Open the Identity Verification tab.

  3. In the Email Verification section:

    • Select Require email verification.

    • Enable Use code verification to require users to enter a code from the verification email.

  4. Click Save.

Step 2: Enable 2FA Authentication Methods

Go to Identity → Security → Authentication and, under Verification Methods, enable your preferred 2FA options:

  • Email – Check Email and click Save.

    Requires email verification to be enabled (see Step 1).

  • SMS/Phone – Check SMS/Phone and click Save.

    Ensure an SMS provider is configured.

  • Authenticator App – Check Authenticator App, enter a name (e.g., SAP Login Authenticator), and click Save.

    Users need an app like Google or Microsoft Authenticator installed.

Step 3: Create a Risk-Based Authentication (RBA) Rule

To apply the 2FA methods during login, set up a Risk-Based Authentication rule:

  1. Open the Risk Based Authentication tab under Identity-> Security in the CDC Console.

  2. Click on Create New Rule, select the template "Enforce TFA for Every Login" and click Next

  3. Provide a rule name and select "Password Login" as the trigger condition.


  4. Under Rule type, select "Global Rule" and define the required criteria below.

  5. In the Actions section, select the 2FA method(s) to enforce (Email, SMS, Authenticator App).

  6. Click Next and set the Scope to apply to the whole group.

  7. Save the Rule.

Once configured, candidates logging in with their credentials will be prompted for an additional verification step, depending on the methods you’ve enabled.

Additional References

For a high-level overview, prerequisites, and benefits of using SAP Customer Data Cloud, refer to the blog.

For detailed information on migrating and enabling SAP CDC for Success Factors Candidate Authentication, refer to the blog.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Employee Central - Automatic Job Relationship Record Creation
entry.content:
Introduction :

In this Blog, I am explaining in detail about how we can make the best use of intelligent services and integration center to automate the process of Job Relationship creation during New Hire.

Details of the Configurations:

Often the maintenance of Job Relationship is missed during new hire creation, and this impacts the workflows and also the PMGM process where it is dependent on the relationships maintained. This Gap can be addressed by leveraging the integration center and intelligent services (ISC) (Thanks to ISC's Event Driven Capability).

Relationship Type :

Relationship Type Label is to be mentioned in the Default Value field , you can check for the Relationship defined under Picklist Center -> jobRelType

 

Event Date :

Event Date is to be mapped to Job Information Start Date

User ID :

Map The User ID to the User ID from Job Information

ReluserID :

RelUserID can either be mentioned in the Default Value or mapped through the calculated Filed if you want it to assign based on conditions.I have mapped it based on the company of the Employee.

and we are all set with the configurations in the Integration Center. Repeat the above steps if you want to maintain Mutiple Job Relationships!

Next is to assign the Integration to the Employee Hire Event which can be done from the Intelligent Services Center.

Please verify if your integration is shown in the Flow

In this case, I am maintaining 2 Relationships (Matrix Manager and HR Manager).

To make all this count, Assigning the Trigger rule is the most important and crucial Task.

Go to Manage Business Configuration -> Assign the Trigger Rule under Job Information 

SAP_EVENT_HIRE is a predelivery event for the ISC by SAP and it is advised not to modify the Rule

Hire a New Employee and See the Magic of Integration in Action!

 

 

Check the Source and this record has been inserted through the Integration Center (API)

Conclusion : 

By leveraging Intelligent Services and the Integration Center, we can seamlessly automate the creation of Job Relationships during the new hire process. This not only eliminates manual steps but also ensures critical relationships like Matrix Manager and HR Manager are consistently and accurately maintained from day one.

Key Benefits:

  • ✅ Improved Data Accuracy – Reduces errors due to missed relationships during hiring.

  • ⚙️ Process Automation – Saves time and effort for HR teams by automating repetitive tasks.

  • 🔄 Workflow Optimization – Ensures downstream processes like workflows and PMGM function smoothly.

  • 📈 Better Compliance & Governance – Maintains standardization across the organization.

entry.title: Antonio de Ancos
entry.content:
More about Antonio de Ancos in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Antonio de Ancos
Location (City, Country): Madrid, Spain
Occupation: Consultant and Instructor

 

 


Antonio, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

I am a lifelong learner and an “occasional” teacher. I believe we live in an age where all kinds of knowledge are at our fingertips, which can sometimes be overwhelming; that’s why my main work is helping others learn faster and more easily. I enjoy sharing good meals with friends, playing sports, and diving into a great book.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I started in 1997 programming ABAP, specifically in the HR module. From there I explored the entire functional side without ever leaving the technical world behind, which led me to wrestling with SAP BTP since its early days (HCP, SCP…). I’ve been an official SAP instructor for over 20 years in both HCM and Technology areas.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?


I didn’t do anything special to become an SAP Champion; someone nominated me, and here I am 😉. I suppose it has something to do with the content I’ve been creating in Spanish over the years—through my blog (www.aancos.com), social media, and a couple of podcasts where I share my professional journey (www.memoriasdeunconsultor.com) and chat with ecosystem experts (www.hablamosdesap.com), including several SAP Champions.


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

In SAP Community I learn from others, since there are people with deep expertise in many of the areas I’m interested in. I find it always easier to learn when someone guides you, although I don’t follow a strict routine.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

I think it’s important to clearly identify a few key thought leaders and accept that you can’t keep up with everything—you risk getting lost in the vast ocean of knowledge. Often, less is more; knowing where to focus is essential.

Antonio's question to you:
Here’s my thought-provoking question: English is undoubtedly the universal language in the technical world, and in SAP in particular (with all due respect to German), so why not create more content for the Spanish-speaking community in their own language?

entry.title: Maintenance Timelines for SAP ERP HCM: What You Need to Know
entry.content:
This blog aims to inform you about the SAP ERP 6.0 maintenance timelines which SAP announced in 2020 and how they apply to your SAP ERP HCM (Human Capital Management) solution. We'll guide you through identifying your release and enhancement package level and outline your options to remain within maintenance.

When Will Maintenance for SAP ERP HCM End?

As outlined in the SAP Release and Maintenance Strategy (login required) and detailed in SAP Note 2881788 (login required) and the Product Availability Matrix (PAM), mainstream maintenance for the latest three enhancement packages for SAP ERP 6.0 – specifically enhancement packages 6, 7, and 8 – runs until December 31, 2027. This is followed by an optional extended maintenance phase lasting until December 31, 2030, which carries an additional cost.

However, it is crucial to note that mainstream maintenance for SAP ERP HCM 6.0 without any enhancement package, as well as SAP ERP HCM 6.0 with enhancement packages 1 to 5, will conclude on December 31, 2025.

How to Find Your Release and Enhancement Package Level

To determine your system's release and enhancement package level, follow these steps:

1. Log on to your system and open the system status:

This can typically be accessed from the main menu or administration settings.

2. Open the product version details:

Look for detailed information about the installed software versions.

3. Locate the entry for SAP_HR and note the release number next to it:

For any SAP ERP 6.0 system, the first digit will be 6. The second digit is not relevant for this check, and the third digit indicates your enhancement package level. For instance, 604 means the system is on SAP ERP 6.0 with enhancement package 4.

What Are Your Options to Stay in Maintenance?

It is important to start planning now, especially if you are using a system with maintenance ending in 2025, as transition projects can take months or even years.

SAP S/4HANA: With SAP's maintenance commitment extending until 2040 and over 20,000 customers already on board, SAP S/4HANA is the natural destination for a short-term technical transition. Many organizations also opt to move to the cloud, choosing RISE with SAP. Reach out to your SAP account executive or SAP partner to explore your options, including opportunities to modernize and transform to SAP SuccessFactors.

SAP Readiness Check: Before making any moves, we strongly recommend starting with the SAP Readiness Check. These tools are included with your maintenance agreement at no extra cost, providing a comprehensive overview of the most important aspects for a transition to SAP S/4HANA. While primarily designed for customers considering a system conversion (a technical transition of an entire SAP ERP system to SAP S/4HANA), SAP Readiness Checks also offer valuable insights for those planning a new implementation.  There are two Readiness Check variants that will support HCM transition. 

First is the SAP Readiness Check for S/4HANA Conversion.  This Readiness Check will provide you with insight into the Simplification Items required for HCM.  Additionally, the SAP Readiness Check for SAP SuccessFactors will provide more extensive insight into which components of the HCM solution are deployed, to what extent it has been customized, and a summary of integrations.  If you are running S/4HANA and HCM in the same landscape, these two Readiness Checks can be run together, for a consolidated view. 

Call to Action

Don’t miss out on these critical steps to ensure your system remains supported:

  1. Review your system to determine product release and associated end of maintenance date per the process outlined above.
  2. Run the SAP Readiness Checks to understand the scope and requirements for your transition.
  3. Explore the HCM EvoKit by registering on the appropriate page.
  4. Share your thoughts and feedback in the comments section below.

By acting now, you can ensure a smooth transition and continued support for your SAP ERP HCM solution.

entry.title: SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Why this matters: the upcoming changes turn what looked like a technical switch into a strategic decision that can affect your budget, compliance posture, and HCM roadmap. Activations of Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA directly influence whether you need additional HCM licenses, which capabilities you can keep on-premise versus in Private Cloud, and how quickly you should plan a move to SuccessFactors for certain functions. Getting ahead of this now helps you avoid unplanned costs or audit exposure, prevents disruption to HR processes tied to payroll, time, and regulatory reporting, and gives you time to align contracts, license product codes, and project timelines. The guidance below distills what’s changing and the practical steps to stay compliant while keeping your transformation on track.

Starting with SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA  will be turned on by default. From this release on, there is no compatibility pack for HCM anymore.  This technical change is not reversible. The licensing requirements are applicable when SAP HCM is utilized beyond the scope of the HR Mini Master, in cases where the customer is conducting HCM processes in the system.

For the technical details, please check the KBA 3443536 - SAP S/4HANA Release 2025 will be delivered with active H4S4_1 Business Function - SAP for Me 

Some functionality is not available in S/4HANA Private Cloud; e.g. SAP Learning Solution is available in S/4HANA on-premise, when moving to Private Cloud, the go-to solution is SuccessFactors Learning.

You can see the details of what features are enabled and what are disabled you can check in the following note 3091160 - SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA – General Approach and Strategy - SAP for Me 

A customer using the HCM compatibility pack today in SAP S/4HANA on-premise can receive a prolongation only if they move to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, via a lift-and-shift (like-for-like) migration that preserves the current release. If the move includes an upgrade to the 2025 release, the H4S4_1 business function will be active by default, and the HCM compatibility pack will no longer be available, so prolongation does not apply.  With the requested change, they would get the prolongation as well in case they directly move to SuccessFactors, which is our strategic intent.

HCM License Materials and Usage Rights 

Customers must also license SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA, at the latest, the first day after the expiry of the Compatibility Package.

Please contact your account executive to plan the license conversion as soon as possible.

entry.title: Plant Maintenance Integration with FICO,MM,PP, QM,HCM,EHS and other modules
entry.content:
Plant maintenance integrates with many of the modules and below are the some of the modules that plant maintenance integrates with: 

FICO(Finance and controlling) :- 

Below are the integration points of plant maintenance with FICO.
Company Code: - A plant will always be assigned to the company code. 
Cost center: - Cost Center is an organizational unit within a controlling area that is used to collect and record costs incurred from business activities.
Investment order: -  investment order needs cost budgeting for an order will be done.
Allocation Structure: -  In the allocation structure the cost elements will be taken from the CO in which these cost elements will gets reflected is any maintenance order have consumption of materials, Labour cost, 3rd party material procurement etc... which will flow the costs to the FI. 
Asset master creation: - When an equipment is being created then the asset will be created with a configuration.
Settlement Of an Order: - The settlement of an order is actually being done for an order because at the cost needs to be settled.
Settlement Profile: - The settlement profile will be assigned to the order type.
Activity Type: - In activity type the price or the cost for labour per hour will be determined by FICO consultant and we need to maintain the activity type in the work center.

PP(Production Planning) :- 
Work Center: - In work center the capacity will be determined by the production planning team. Here the capacity refers to the availability of people and resources for maintenance work.
Equipment Master Data: - In equipment master data there is a field work center in the Location in which we need to give the production planning work center and whereas in the organization. 
Spare Part Preparation: - For example the spare part cannot be procured externally then the spare part will be produced by the production order and the settlement rule of order will be done to the maintenance order.
Refurbishment of Material:- Refurbishment of material will be done if any material in production needs to be repaired as soon as possible then we will just refurbish the material and replace the material within the machine as it was there before the breakdown.

MM(Material Management):-
Components:- The components that are required for maintenance of machine will be taken from the inventory.
Service Entry Sheet:- To procure the service from external that is the maintenance has to be done for a machine and there is no team that is present in the plant(internal team) then we will just raise purchase requestion from the maintenance order and after it the material management people will procure the service through ML81N."
Split valuation:- Split valuation for a material has to be configured so that we can perform the refurbishment order.
Details of plant:- The details of plant related namely Purchase Organization, Vendor, Supplier, Outline agreement number etc..
Serial Number Profile:- A serial number profile must be configured for the material to enable the creation of equipment for that material.
Goods Issue:- Goods issue needs to be done for the order otherwise the technician cannot perform the maintenance activities that are present in the order.
Goods Receipt:- Goods receipt has to be done for the Internal Refurbishment Order and the settlement will be done for the material.
Material Reservation:- after creating the maintenance order the materials will be reserved in the inventory automatically.
Procurement:- Procuring of non-stock material, service entry sheet through purchase requestion.

Quality Management:- 
CatLog Profile:- Catlog profile will be configured by the quality management team and it will be assigned for the equipment , functional location.
Calibration Order:- In calibration order inspection will be done and thereby the equipment can be used or not will be determined by the quality management team.

SD(Sales And Distribution):- 
The place where the sales and distribution as well as plant maintenance will gets integrated is in customer service module.

EHS(Environment Health & Safety):-
The integration part of PM with EHS comes only at the product safety, Work permit - while performing any maintenance at the dangerous or hazardous material or equipment's.

FREM(Flexible Real Estate Management):- 
Flexible real estate management and plant maintenance both comes under Enterprise Asset Management in SAP S/4 Hana.
Real Estate Object: - Real estate object will be considered as functional location/equipment.
Work order:- Notification and work order management à maintenance requests originating from RE-FX can be turned into PM notifications/ orders but this will be done with the help of CRM.
Service Provider Coordination: - PM order can trigger external services with the help of MM (material management) to work on RE-FX managed asset.

HCM(Human Capital Management):-
Person Responsible:- Here the person can be assigned to the work order , work center, Technical Object, Operations in work order too.

DMS(Document Management System):-
Documents can be uploaded for the technical objects, notifications , work orders etc... for information or to follow the rules to keep the equipment runs smoothly.

The above are some of the modules for which the plant maintenance will integrate with.

Hope its informative and feel free to comment for any improvements or suggestions.

Regards,
Neeraj.
